page.title: 04Local History
page.content: The{Manor}of the{Prebend End}of Buckingham cum Gawcott. This Manor was the{Church's}until the reformation. At the time of the {Doomsday Survey}this Manor consisted of land enough fo four ploughs; a{mill }valued at 10, with meadow and wood for fences worth in all 6 in Buckingham and {one hide}in Gawcott. In October 1764 a lot of people went to court to see which seeds could be sown and what animals could be kept. Later,all the manor fields were{cut up {into furlongs}and given a name. Their names have been used for roads in some of the new estates. eg{Bushey Close {and Hare Close. The open fields were called Great Portfield, Little Portfield. Lower Portfield Way and Portfield Close have been named after them.
